description.narrative: Safetypay creates an alternative online payment system that benefits merchants in countries with underdeveloped online payment systems and allows them to export their goods by selling them online. The company''s system provides banked low income consumers in developing countries the ability to benefit from the lower cost, greater transparency and wider availability of goods and services delivered by ecommerce from which they are otherwise excluded because they do not qualify for credit cards or credit cards are simply too expensive. The company''s system creates incentives to obtain bank accounts rather than just a prepaid card or another transactional payment service and thereby supports financial inclusion. As an investor the IFC can ensure that the benefits offered by Safetypay are increasingly made available to consumers and merchants in developing countries. Banks in developing countries which often do not generate much or any income from issuing credit cards and merchant acquiring (enabling merchants to accept credit cards) gain a new source of fee income and can monetize their online banking service. Safetypay is already working on technology that will enable unbanked customers to purchase goods online by obtaining vouchers from banks which generate fee income and cross selling opportunities for the banks and, again, creates an opportunity for financial inclusion.

Safetypay enables consumers without credit cards to buy goods and services online (e-commerce) by paying directly from their bank account using online banking. The system is more secure than payment by credit card, has lower cost and risk for retailers and benefits countries with low payment card penetration. The companys service can expand the availability of ecommerce alongside financial inclusion strategies without the need to push people onto costly payment cards. It expands the ability of companies in developing countries to sell goods and services into other countries online and increases exports.
